agent.text: Hello! I'm Alex, and I'll be conducting your interview today. This interview has two parts: first, you'll introduce yourself and share your background, and then we'll discuss your past experience in detail. Let's begin - Pranav Mishra, why don't you tell me a bit about yourself?
I'm looking forward to hearing about your personal projects or interests, Pranav! What have you pursued outside of your academic and professional experiences in AI or technology?

Thank you for sharing that, Pranav! Now, let's delve deeper into your past experiences as they relate to the AI Engineer position you're applying for. You mentioned creating a reinforcement learning game agent called Snake AI MLOps. Could you walk me through that project? What were your goals, the technologies you used, and any challenges
I'm curious to hear about your selection process, Pranav! How did you choose the four reinforcement learning algorithms for your project, and what criteria did you use to evaluate their performance?

Thank you so much for sharing your experiences with me today, Pranav! I appreciate your insights into your projects, especially your work with reinforcement learning algorithms and your focus on healthcare applications. It's clear that you have a strong foundation in AI concepts, which is a great fit for the AI Engineer role. 

Wishing you the best of luck in your job search, and I hope to see you succeed in your future endeavors! Goodbye!

user.text: Hi. I'm Pranav. I'm a recent grad from UIC with a master
in computer science.
And I've been working as a research software engineer at UIC's BI labs.
Building on health care applications.
Virtual reality applications in medical domain as well as multi agent research.
I've had many
personal projects. I've made games, mobile games, computer games,
AI games. As well, I made a reinforcement learning game agent.
Called Snake AI MLOps.
Yeah. It was a project using c plus plus and
and. I made the models in Python, but then I converted them
to run inference
on Libtash because it was a c plus plus game.
And it was basically a snake agent comparing four different
reinforcement learning algorithms and how they work.
I just use for legacy systems where
I've looked on the most
first most popular reinforcement learning technique, which was the
queue table. And then I did
deep queue as well as policy network.
And then some later on, like,
policy act.

And other.
Stuff. So it was more of a
comparison tool. It was more of me learning the algorithms and the maths behind it.
It.
Yep.
